I had a little bit
of a choice to make what hat to wear
coming here if I was going to just try to be HCI.

I started to lean. It just seems more
fun and interesting to be computational
social science today. It maybe is worth talking a
little bit about training.
I came out of-- I'm very proud of my training. I got to pick it.

And so I was in the cognitive
science program and sort of an information
science program.

And I came out of the
Ostrom workshop, which is devoted to the
study of the commons,

and bringing those together is
a lot of fun and sort of defines what's fun about
being an academic

and a researcher, which is, I
feel like a social obligation

to gamble with our
career, to learn new, exciting, strange stuff. And so one thing
representing me is the idea

of the commons as a framework
for collective behavior, collective intelligence.

The idea of the
internet as a laboratory for designing better social
institutions, for everybody

all over the place. Personally, I have a background
as an intentional community

organizer, cooperative
housing and so on. And this is where a lot of
practitioner synergy comes in

and the questions I'm
interested in, and then the cognitive science
dimension of all of this.

So understanding
individual reasoners.

Elinor Ostrom was a
big influence on me. Governing the Commons was
a big influence on me. And it raises
fundamental questions

about how we work together
and get along together that with global impact--

if you think about every
major problem facing humanity and you're going
to find a tragedy of the commons underneath it.

And so if we can find smaller
tragedies of the commons, smaller collective
action problems,

and tackle those in a more
tractable way, if we can find a domain like the internet where
they're all over the place,

then we have the
kind of model system we need to potentially
scale and address bigger global challenges.

Here's a great example. This is a Minecraft
server with deforestation.

Trees go down and
buildings go up. So, you know if you can't
keep the kitchen sink clean,

how do we store the Earth? Minecraft happens to
give kids training in managing finite
resources together

for their own personal goals. Not because they're being
told that natural resource

depletion is important, but
because they experience it. And so what are they
learning about governance and the process?

And what folk theory
of collective action are they picking
up in the process as they solve these problems
personally among themselves?

This is what's
exciting and powerful about online communities
as laboratories for collective action.

So that's a little bit
the thesis for today. With online communities,
computational social scientists

can test general principles
of institution design and performance.

There's a reason that my
audience of a lot of my work is HCI is because no one else
thinks my behavior is real.

No one else thinks that
lessons from online behavior can transfer outside of it.

And most people still
think that the structure of online communities, what's
special about them, what

works about them is
specific to the internet, that there's not
generalizable lessons. And so one of the challenges
of my work and my career

is getting people actually
outside of computer science to see the potential
of these model systems.

And so you just have
to make the case. Fruit flies are a
model of humans.

That's just how it
is and how it's been. It's a very successful model. It's just you have
to pay attention to what you're modeling.

Mice are a model of humans. And so in the same
way, online communities really are a model of
institutional and organizational

processes. And there's a reason why this
is really important to keep hitting, is that if
you're a cell biologist,

you study lots of cells. You don't really do
case studies on cells. If you're a psychologist,
you study lots of people.

So if you're a
social scientist, you should study lots of societies. And how do you do that? There's only one Earth.

There's only like 250 countries. And that's not bad
in for regression.

But if you have a
whole discipline that only says the same 255, then
even if no paper is p-hacked,

you kind of have a
discipline that's p-hacked. And so how do you just
get a lot of societies that are comparable?

And this is why we go online. You have the societal
unit of analysis. You have real people.

You have a simplified
environment, almost halfway to experiment, but it's still real. You have multi-level data, full
granularity, individual level

data, and social and
population, which is populations of populations.

And this is what you
need to study emergence, to study successful governance
as an emergent property

of individual interactions. It's general enough in the sense
that tragedies of the commons

happen there. And so we can study
them and take them out. You have people with high
motivation, clear goals,

and you have selection
on performance, which is even if you're
getting sample bias, where you're not getting all the
communities that ever existed,

you're getting the
ones that survive. So at least, you're
seeing the good ones. It's sometimes a weakness,
but there's something to it,

and you see it-- so
there's Wikipedia, but there's the Wikipedias. There's 300 languages, 300-plus
language editions of Wikipedia.

In one study, we're
looking at the order in which they adopted policies.

Like here, you have the
vandalism policy to understand if there's-- for many different cultures
accomplishing one goal,

are there 300 paths,
300 development paths for mature organizational
process, or is there kind of one

because your mission
is that strong? We have work on Reddit, where
you have from the serious

to the frivolous. I think the shower
thoughts rules, r/showerthoughts
rules are really fun. One of them is shower
thoughts are not thoughts

about being in the shower. The Apache Software Foundation
is one of many open source

software foundations
that provide a kind of stable
institutional environment for lots of open source
projects, each of which

are self-governing. So you get a standard
to be able to compare, in this very important domain
that runs the internet.

And then really close
to my heart is-- I'm going to share some old

exciting things

of 300,000 servers, we got a lot of visits.

So you run a Minecraft
server and it's a computer, so it has limited CPU,
RAM, and bandwidth.

These are physical resources. And if you log on to
server and go to any sheep or set to any
fires, you'll eat up

all the CPU and
all the bandwidth, and everyone else is going
to have a bad experience. That is the tragedy
of the commons.

These are when you share
a server, your CPU, RAM, bandwidth, your
physical resources are a common pool resource.

And other people can
abuse those resources. And so you have to install
a governance system in order

to manage that. It turns out there's a whole
plug-in ecosystem in Minecraft for installing social hierarchy.

The idea of private
property, punishment, peer monitoring, top-down
monitoring, peer communication,

top-down communication,
when something bad happens, what do you want to do? Do you want to prevent
it in the future

by turning some actions off? Or do you want to
remediate bad behavior? Do you want to
install tools that

make it easy to undo bad things
when they happen so that you don't prevent people from doing
the same behavior for something

exciting. These are all choices
and strategies that you see kids making.

And so what do they do? First, this is a

your community was that

We're going to call
that not successful. We'll say you're successful
if you broke the top two rows.

And you'll see when

is that your core group

size was proportional
to your target size. So that upper diagonal, those
are all the most successful communities.

are unsuccessful.

And we'll call the upper

OK. Questions are welcome. I like it. So now we're going to--

OK, there's different
problems you have to solve as an administrator. There's bad behavior,
plugins for that. There's physical resources,
plug-ins for that,

and there's virtual resources,
trees, and crops, and so on. So there's different
problems to solve.

And then there's different
ways of solving them. You can solve
communication plug ins, information plug ins, market.

You can install the
idea of markets. And of course, you can further
empower the administrator. You can take someone
who's already in charge

and give them more, or
increase the distance between what they can
do and what others can do by forbidding actions.

So what you can see
just by squinting is that most governance effort
goes into managing bad behavior.

The manner in which
that's done is by further empowering the administrator. That's just overall.

Then the brightness
of green and blue becomes stronger
the bigger you get. So bigger servers
have more focus

on further empowering
the administrator. Bigger servers have more
problems managing bad behavior. And then those arrows are--

things that came out with
significant P values. So interestingly, a
lot while a lot of this is correlated with
size, only one thing

is correlated with
success, which is actually focused on physical resource
management, CPU, RAM, bandwidth.

But more generally,
just more rules was better, especially as you
get larger and more successful.

That came out very cleanly. And then there was
institutional diversity. Did you introduce a
variety of solution types

to solve a variety of problems? And we saw that the greater
your diversity, the greater--

the larger you were. But also there's evidence that
you were also more successful. There's some ambiguity,
very quibbly.

But there was also
a relationship to success, a significant
relationship to success for--

well, we're going to call it
institutional diversity, which is that don't be an ideologue. Don't just solve
with a top down,

don't solve everything
with democracy. Democracy is not made
to solve everything. Don't solve everything
in this way or that way.

Use a variety of institutional
types and problems and processes to tackle
your communities,

resource management challenges. We have some offshoot
papers from this. A nice thing that came out is
that in the Minecraft study,

in a couple others, you
see a lot more focus on-- when you write a
written rule, you

can say you must not
do this or else-- you can say you really
shouldn't do this.

Or you can say,
here are the things that can be done, and just
let people decide from there.

So we're going to call
that last one a strategy. We'll call the first one a rule. And overwhelmingly,
you see a lot of focus

on norms, which is you
should behave this way. We're not going to
tell you what to do.

This is how you should behave. This top row, all that blue is
showing this across platforms,

very general result. And similarly, when
you're making rules, you can use them to
define abstractions.

A shower thought
is not a thought about being in the shower. We're going to call that
a constitutive rule. It defines an abstraction
that's relevant to the community

that you then regulate
behavior over. And overwhelmingly, those
are very small proportion

of governance. While most of it is about
telling people what to do, defining behavior
on roles that are

defined by constitutive rules. So we're getting some
governance style. Another offshoot project. I was really proud
of this student.

The price equation is a result
from mathematical biology.
And it says that when-- so traits occur.

And sometimes traits become
more popular than other traits. Is it because they're good? Or is it because they're
random drift, or social, just

kind of incidental stuff? There's lots of bad reasons
why things become popular. When something's popular, it's
not always because it's good.

And with this mathematical
result in theoretical biology, we were able to-- meh-- fit to-- ghosts
changed my slide.

We were able to map it back
to governance choices in this ecosystem of self-hosted
Minecraft servers to show that--

This focus on administrative
style governance,

top-down bureaucracy,
top-down domination

was positively selected for
and was not a result of drift. Whereas other kind of styles
of governance that became

ascendant at times was driven
by drift, randomness, choice, other things, but not
because of selective benefit.

You're more likely to survive
if you focus on that governance style in this ecosystem. Plenty to say about that.
If you have questions. Questions? OK, I'll keep moving.

Remember, the context
is that unlike the US or in some other

and go to any other. So there's what is called
the libertarian theory.

I was really apprehensive

which is that if tyrants

have to compete for citizens-- this is a fictional
utopia, Robert Nozick,

important economic thinker. If there's tyrants and they
have to compete for citizens, they'll act as if
they're benevolent.

And so the argument
could be that Minecraft is an implementation of
this libertarian utopia.

And that's why this works. That's why it's effective
to empower administrators.

That plus-- Minecraft

concept that we just kind of baked feudalism

we think of as empowering,
all these online communities. They're all assuming
and top-down leadership. And so what do we do about that?

And just like all

about behavior, lots

we don't have a lot of hard

what people actually do. You can call it de

You can call it rules and

It's been theorized

Should they be the same? When they're different,

and embarrassing.

It's embarrassing for

So the Apache
Software Foundation is one of many
software foundations that was started around the
Apache web server, which you
interact with many times a day. And it hosts lots of projects.

And those projects,
they get kind of legal administrative
support so the coders can code, which they like to do. They don't want to be governors.

But in exchange,
they have to adopt the Apache way of running, which
is a specific governance style.

So you're a halfway successful
open source project. You run how you run, you
join this incubator program.

And you get a mentor,
you get guidelines, and you have to
hit certain boxes. You hit those
boxes, you run how--

you have adopted
our way of being you now earn access to our resources
because you run how we think

open source should be run. And so you either graduate
or retire into the incubator.

And that's important. We have a binary
outcome for 300 projects that all started very
different, but are all

trying to accomplish the same
way of running, same uniform definition of success. That's the key of why
I took this project

on because like binary
success outcome, you never get that over
a population of hundreds

of communities. So here it is. This is the Apache
way that you have

to adopt if you're going to join
this community of communities. You're going to run
an earned authority.

You're going to be
community of peers. You're going to have open
communications, which means all project,
relevant discussions

are going to be in
public email lists. That's how we got do we
run how we say we run.

It's the data set that makes
the question possible to ask. Consensus decision making
and responsible oversight.
It's a great model. I admire them, actually. So founded a while.

They've been going for a while. Projects are
autonomous, but they have guidance and constraints.

And the incubator provides a lot
of services from administration branding, licensing, and so on.

Here's a rule, and it's got

These are the kinds of

this into something that we can compare to a written rule.

One thing we're going to do. We're going to use SRL as a
natural language processing technique.

So one thing we have is a lot of
the sentences are complicated. And they do a lot of stuff. And so we're going to
take a complex sentence,

like the one on top original
policy, or this one, and then we're going to
represent it, break it

into parts that are kind of
semantic, and kind of syntactic. That's what semantic
role parsing does.

And then we're going
to reconstitute them into clean sentences
that are easy to analyze.

So we're doing a
bunch of rearranging. This lets us get rid
of passive voice. It lets us do all
kinds of stuff that

creates the
possibility of apples to apples, comparisons of
what people are talking about and what the rules say.

In the process, we get
benefits from something called institutional grammar.

This is a technique
developed by people who study common pool
resource systems in nature

structure on. So it's kind of like a formal
method that has so much overlap with natural language
processing that we

can automate big chunks
of it and get insights about governance structure from
someone's idea of what a shower

thought should be. Our pipelines overall
are going to look like a lot of text
processing and cleaning,

and all this, including all
this semantic role work. Then we're going to turn every
single one of those sentences

into a point in high
dimensional space. And when you're point in
high dimensional space, you have a distance
from other points.

In high dimensional space, you
get a distance of every sentence from every other sentence,
every sentence from every rule.

With that, we'll
do some clustering. And so we'll say,
well, this whole space

can be cut up into
maybe 200 clusters. And out of those clusters, both
the sentences end up in a bunch.
